Dropping of a Bomb on Danish Territory.
3. Reference was made by the Prime Minister to the allegation in the Press that it was a British bomb which had fallen yesterday on the Danish port of Esbjerg.
The Secretary of State for Air said that up to the present there was no evidence to support this allegation, though it was possible that it might be well founded.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Turkey.
(Previous Reference: W.M. (39), Conclusions Minute 1.)
2nd
4. A discussion took place on methods of expediting the Franco-Anglo-Turkish Treaty negotiations.
The War Cabinet were unanimous in the view that it was now essential that Turkey should declare herself on the side of Great Britain and France without further delay. Reference was made to the dangers and difficulties we had created for ourselves in the last War by neglecting the opportunity of securing Turkey's friendship (or neutrality) beforehand.
There was no difference of opinion that at the present juncture it would be worth paying a stiff price to avoid a repetition of similar dangers and difficulties.
[19968]

The draft Treaty would not bring Turkey into the War on our side unless the War spread to the Mediterranean area. Some members of the War Cabinet, however, suggested that it was desirable to look further ahead, and that it might be possible to regard the signature of the Agreement now under negotiation as a prelude to Turkey's entry into the War against Germany.
The view was also advanced that, after the signature of the Treaty, it should be possible to obtain Turkey's permission for a few British warships to enter the Black Sea, This would have a most salutary effect, particularly on Roumania.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that Turkey would have to become a belligerent before she would be entitled, under the Montreux Convention, to give permission for the warships of other belligerents to pass through the Bosphorus and the Dardanelles. He was preparing a note on the use of the Straits, which he would circulate to the War Cabinet at an early date.
The latest reports from the British Ambassador in Turkey as regards the progress of the Treaty negotiations indicated that comprehensive proposals were now on their way from the Turkish side. It would be desirable to await these proposals, although it was fully expected that Turkey would maintain her demand for a gold bullion loan. We were, of course, unwilling to see our gold reserve further diminished. Further, it was very important to induce France to share in any gold loan to Turkey (as she had shared in the Polish loan), more particularly since the grant of a gold loan to Turkey would be the signal for similar demands from other countries.
The discussion was not carried further in view of the fact that the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs had arranged to meet later in the day to discuss the matter.

He had therefore issued instructions to the effect that the four men should be handed over forthwith.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.

Air Operations.
(Previous Reference: W.M. (39), 2nd Conclusions, Minute 5.)
8. The Secretary of State for Air gave an account of the attack carried out on the German Fleet in the afternoon of the 4th September, in which he referred to the bad weather conditions in which the attack had been carried out, the extent of the damage inflicted, and of the losses sustained.
The Secretary of State for Air also referred briefly to the leaflet-dropping carried out over Germany on the night of the 3rd-4th September, and again on the night of the 4th-5th September.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement, and expressed their high appreciation of the great gallantry with which the attack had been carried out.
